texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Managing iptables gets a lot easier with  firewalld . You can manage rules for the IPv4 and IPv6 stacks using the same commands and it provides fine-grained controls for various "zones" of network sources and destinations.
texts.text: Managing iptables gets a lot easier with  firewalld . You can manage rules for the IPv4 and IPv6 stacks using the same commands and it provides fine-grained controls for various "zones" of network sources and destinations.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's an example of allowing an arbitrary port (for  netdata ) through the firewall with iptables and firewalld on Fedora:
texts.text: Here's an example of allowing an arbitrary port (for  netdata ) through the firewall with iptables and firewalld on Fedora:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
## iptables
iptables -A INPUT -j ACCEPT -p tcp --dport 19999
ip6tables -A INPUT -j ACCEPT -p tcp --dport 19999
service iptables save
service ip6tables save

## firewalld
firewall-cmd --add-port=19999/tcp --permanent
texts.text:
## iptables
iptables -A INPUT -j ACCEPT -p tcp --dport 19999
ip6tables -A INPUT -j ACCEPT -p tcp --dport 19999
service iptables save
service ip6tables save

## firewalld
firewall-cmd --add-port=19999/tcp --permanent

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: allows us to allow a TCP port through the firewall with a much simpler interface and the change is made permanent with the
texts.text: allows us to allow a TCP port through the firewall with a much simpler interface and the change is made permanent with the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can always test a change with firewalld without making it permanent:
texts.text: You can always test a change with firewalld without making it permanent:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
firewall-cmd --add-port=19999/tcp
## Do your testing to make sure everything works.
firewall-cmd --runtime-to-permanent
texts.text:
firewall-cmd --add-port=19999/tcp
## Do your testing to make sure everything works.
firewall-cmd --runtime-to-permanent

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: argument tells firewalld to write the currently active firewall configuration to disk.
texts.text: argument tells firewalld to write the currently active firewall configuration to disk.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I use  mosh  with most of my servers since it allows me to reconnect to an existing session from anywhere in the world and it makes higher latency connections less painful. Mosh requires a range of UDP ports (60000 to 61000) to be opened.
texts.text: I use  mosh  with most of my servers since it allows me to reconnect to an existing session from anywhere in the world and it makes higher latency connections less painful. Mosh requires a range of UDP ports (60000 to 61000) to be opened.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We can do that easily in firewalld:
texts.text: We can do that easily in firewalld:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We can also see the rule it added to the firewall:
texts.text: We can also see the rule it added to the firewall:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# iptables-save | grep 61000
-A IN_public_allow -p udp -m udp --dport 60000:61000 -m conntrack --ctstate NEW,UNTRACKED -j ACCEPT
# ip6tables-save | grep 61000
-A IN_public_allow -p udp -m udp --dport 60000:61000 -m conntrack --ctstate NEW,UNTRACKED -j ACCEPT
texts.text:
# iptables-save | grep 61000
-A IN_public_allow -p udp -m udp --dport 60000:61000 -m conntrack --ctstate NEW,UNTRACKED -j ACCEPT
# ip6tables-save | grep 61000
-A IN_public_allow -p udp -m udp --dport 60000:61000 -m conntrack --ctstate NEW,UNTRACKED -j ACCEPT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you haven't used firewalld yet, give it a try! There's a lot more documentation on common use cases in the  Fedora firewalld documentation .
texts.text: If you haven't used firewalld yet, give it a try! There's a lot more documentation on common use cases in the  Fedora firewalld documentation .
